choices.B: vpn 1 ip route 0.0.0.0/0 vpn 1 interface ge0/0 ip address 172.16.0.1/24 nat
choices.A: vpn 1 interface ge0/1 ip address 172.16.0.1/24 vpn 512 ip route 0.0.0.0/0 vpn 0
choices.C: vpn 0 ip route 0.0.0.0/0 vpn 0 vpn 1 interface ge0/1 ip address 172.16.0.1/24 nat
choices.D: vpn 0 interface ge0/0 ip address 172.16.0.1/24 nat vpn 1 ip route 0.0.0.0/0 vpn 0

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

Enable NAT on the transport interface. VPN 0
Create static route in the service VPN to direct traffic out of the NATed transport.

The Service VPN (1) has a default route to VPN 0 (WAN Transport) which requires NAT to be enabled to forward public/private traffic from WAN to LAN and vice versa
Option D is the only answer here!

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the components from the left onto the corresponding Cisco NFV Infrastructure Building Blocks on the right. Not all options are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content: answer is B , must establish with same color using restrict

on the other hand, the question says "The requirement is to have IPsec VPN tunnels established between the same colors", without a "restrict" they will still established TLOCs with the same color, as well as with different ones, but it would meet the requirement
any thoughts?
But also A meets the requirement as long as there is one connection...

However this is a spurious question the Restrict keyword with the COLOR option prevents attempts to establish BFD sessions to TLOCs with different colors.
i.e., if 'color mpls restrict' is configured, the TLOC will establish BFD sessions only with MPLS TLOC color nodes.

The public colors are:-
3g, biz-internet, blue, bronze, custom1, custom2, custom3, default, gold, green, lte, public-internet, red, and silver.

So technically Options A,B and C are valid and satisfies the question in hand!

If I were to use logical traditional Cisco naming conventions and consistency.
I believe the answer to be B

The way the question appears here it could be B or C and while B is the better choice since has internet label, it's using private addressing which could indicate C is correct choice unless there is a typo as assili was possibly implying.

comments.content:
You are right highly likely.
Otherwise these answer options are bad joke.

discussion.content: B is the better answer with reference color to internet. C will work too

comments.content: The naming of colors is not important as long as they are consistent

"two branch WAN Edge devices where an Internet connection is available".
Should be B.

discussion.content: why C and not B?

choices.C: ICMP loss and latency metrics to the SaaS application
choices.B: BFD loss and latency metrics to the gateway site
choices.D: HTTP loss and latency metrics to the gateway site
choices.E: BFD loss and latency metrics to the SaaS application
choices.A: HTTP loss and latency metrics to the SaaS application

questions.question_text: Which two metrics must a cloud Edge router use to pick the optimal path for a SaaS application reachable via a gateway site? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I think the correct answer should be AB.
-The gateway vEdge uses HTTP to obtain SaaS application performance information
- The client vEdge will use BFD over the IPSec tunnel to the gateway site to obtain client>gateway path performance information
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/SDWAN/CVD-SD-WAN-Cloud-onRamp-for-SaaS-Deployment-Guide-2018JUL.pdf

Selected Answer: AB
A and B

https://www.networkacademy.io/ccie-enterprise/sdwan/cloud-onramp-for-saas
according to above site vedge use http ping to saas site for loss and latency that is option A and also vedge check tunnel health with gateway site with BFD that is option B

Selected Answer: AB
Correct AB

By design the c-edge router looks at the loss and latency on the paths of the
gateway sites and calculates vQoe scores for each SaaS application and path
based on that information. The VEdge router picks the optimal path via
these methods

So HTTPs to obtain SaaS application performance and BFD over IPSec tunnel to
the gateway site (to obtain gateway path performance information)

Option [A] and [B]

Link Reference:-
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/SDWAN/CVD-SD-WAN-Cloud-onRamp-for-SaaS-Deployment-Guide-2018JUL.pdf
(Page 4/6)

We dont ping the SaaS application, we send HTTP probes.
BFD is used between the 2 WAN Edges as usual, and HTTP between the Gateway site and the SaaS app.

Selected Answer: AB
This is definitely A&B.

Selected Answer: AB
HTTP is used the the SAAS and BFD to the GW

Selected Answer: AB
I believe HTTP is used the the SAAS and BFD to the GW
